contentfulPage.title: Long term illness
contentfulPage.metaDescription: Find out what happens if you’re off work because of illness for more than 28 days, and how the council will help you get to work.

childMarkdownRemark.html: If you’ve been away from work for 28 days or more, we’ll need to meet you to find out more about your illness. We won’t put pressure on you to come back, but we will do all we can to help you get ready for work again.

A serious illness or health condition is tough to deal with and we are here to support you through it. Your manager will need to understand your situation in detail, so we need you to be clear and honest with us.

We have a standard 3 stage process for dealing with long term illness, which makes sure we do all we can to get you back to work. It also means we can be sure that you really are ill. 

Our process means that if in the end you can’t come back to work, you will have been treated with complete fairness.

Your manager will get in touch with you to find out more about your situation and set up a meeting. It’s important you attend the meetings your manager arranges.

If you don’t feel well enough to meet at work, then you can ask to meet somewhere else, for example at home.

During the meeting, your manager will find out more about your illness. Afterwards they may ask you to see an occupational health adviser who specialises in the well-being of people at work. The health adviser will get a clear understanding of the health problems you’re facing and how they may affect your ability to work. They may ask to see a medical report from your GP.

Your manager will then make a plan to help you get back to work. For example, you might start back at work for only a few hours per week and then gradually build up to your full time hours. Or you may need support when you come back to work, such as special equipment like a supportive chair or longer comfort breaks.

Your manager will arrange a follow up meetingto see if you're improving and decide what to do next.

If you’re still not able to work after the plan has been put into action, you’ll need to go to a formal meeting. You can take a work colleague with you or someone from your Union, if you want to. If you haven't already spoken with occupational health, your manager might ask you to talk to a health adviser. Your manager will look at all the information and decide what to do next.

This could include reducing your work hours, bringing in special equipment to help you at work, as well as any other adjustments we can make to help you get back on track.

If your illness means you still can’t work, we’ll have to consider all other options.

These include making adjustments to how you work, or suggesting other roles for you, and if you need to stop working for the council completely. We will discuss all this with you in detail before making any decision, and make sure we have the most up to date information from your doctor.

We’ll follow our Health and Attendance policy and the Equality Act 2010 at every stage.

If you do need to stop working for the council, you may be able to take early retirement for health reasons if you have more than 3 months’ pensionable service.

But before we get to that point, we will still do all we can to get you back to work with us.
If you don’t agree with what’s decided at stage 3, you can appeal against it. Your appeal will be seen by someone other than your manager, so you get treated fairly.
You will continue to be paid your normal salary for a period of time, before moving to half pay. How long this lasts depends on how long you’ve worked at the council.
